facts.text: Judgment delivered by SARKAR, J. on April 4, 1961.

facts.text: Petition raises question of violation of fundamental right to hold property under Art. 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition raising a question of violation of the fundamental right to hold property guaranteed by Art. 19  1   f  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Order made under Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 declaring two houses to be evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: It arises out of an order made under the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950, declaring two houses to be evacuee property. What had happened was that

facts.text: Two notices issued under s. 7 of the Act sometime in September 1951 to Nusrat Ali and Fateh Ali requiring show cause why declare them evacuees and two houses evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: What had happened was that sometime in September, 1951, two numberices were issued under s. 7 of the Act addressed respectively to Nusrat Ali and Fateh Ali, requiring them to show cause why they should number be declared evacuees and their properties, being the two houses in dispute, to be evacuee property.

facts.text: Neither Nusrat Ali nor Fateh Ali appeared.

anchor.surface_text: Neither of these two persons having appeared, a declaration was made by the Custodian on January 10, 1952, under that section that Nusrat Ali and Fateh Ali were evacuees and the houses were evacuee property.

facts.text: Custodian made declaration on January 10, 1952 under s. 7 that Nusrat Ali and Fateh Ali were evacuees and the houses were evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: a declaration was made by the Custodian on January 10, 1952, under that section that Nusrat Ali and Fateh Ali were evacuees and the houses were evacuee property. Upon such declaration the houses vested in the Custodian under the provision of s. 8 of the Act and he took possession of them.

facts.text: Upon declaration, the two houses vested in the Custodian under s. 8 and he took possession.

anchor.surface_text: Upon such declaration the houses vested in the Custodian under the provision of s. 8 of the Act and he took possession of them. These houses were the property of one Khadim Ali who had never been declared an evacuee and had died on or about October 1, 1950,

facts.text: The two houses were the property of Khadim Ali.

anchor.surface_text: These houses were the property of one Khadim Ali who had never been declared an evacuee and had died on or about October 1, 1950, leaving three sons and five daughters, who thereupon became entitled to them in certain shares.

facts.text: Khadim Ali had never been declared an evacuee.

anchor.surface_text: These houses were the property of one Khadim Ali who had never been declared an evacuee and had died on or about October 1, 1950, leaving three sons and five daughters, who thereupon became entitled to them in certain shares.

facts.text: Khadim Ali died on or about October 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: who had never been declared an evacuee and had died on or about October 1, 1950, leaving three sons and five daughters, who thereupon became entitled to them in certain shares. Nusrat Ali and Fateh Ali were two of the sons of Khadim Ali.

facts.text: Khadim Ali left three sons and five daughters who became entitled to the houses in certain shares.

anchor.surface_text: leaving three sons and five daughters, who thereupon became entitled to them in certain shares. Nusrat Ali and Fateh Ali were two of the sons of Khadim Ali. The Petitioners are his other son and two of his daughters.

facts.text: Nusrat Ali and Fateh Ali were two of the sons of Khadim Ali.

anchor.surface_text: Nusrat Ali and Fateh Ali were two of the sons of Khadim Ali. The Petitioners are his other son and two of his daughters. No numberice under s. 7 had at any time been issued to them number were they ever declared to be evacuees.

facts.text: Petitioners are the other son and two daughters of Khadim Ali.

anchor.surface_text: The Petitioners are his other son and two of his daughters. No numberice under s. 7 had at any time been issued to them number were they ever declared to be evacuees. These facts are number in dispute.

facts.text: Male petitioner filed appeal to Custodian-General on behalf of all petitioners against order of January 10, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: One of such steps appears to have been an appeal preferred by the male petitioner on behalf of all the petitioners to the Custodian-General against the order of January 10, 1952. On this appeal being rejected, they moved this Court by the present petition.

facts.text: Appeal to Custodian-General rejected.

anchor.surface_text: On this appeal being rejected, they moved this Court by the present petition. The question is whether the Custodian was entitled to declare the entirety of the two houses evacuee property and deprive the petitioners of their rights in them.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed on sole ground that it was filed beyond prescribed time.

anchor.surface_text: Then again the appeal did number decide any question as to the right of Zafar Ali to the houses for, it was dismissed on the sole ground that it bad been filed beyond the time prescribed for it.

facts.text: Counsel for respondents concedes that female petitioners' interest could not be affected by order under s. 7.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the respondents, the officers companycerned with evacuee properties, companycedes that so far as the female petitioners were companycerned, their interest companyld number in any way be affected by the order made under s. 7 of the Act.

facts.text: Zafar Ali was not a party to the proceeding in which the order of January 10, 1952 was made.

anchor.surface_text: Zafar Ali was number a patty to the proceeding in which the order in dispute had been made. Strictly speaking, numberappeal by him against that order lay or was necessary.

facts.text: Petitioner Zafar Ali claims father left a will giving him larger share.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention here that the petitioner Zafar Ali claims that his father left a will giving him a larger share in the houses than he would have got on intestacy.

facts.text: Court allows petition and sets aside order of January 10, 1952 insofar as it affected petitioners' rights.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we allow the petition and set aside the order of January 10, 1952, in so far as it affected the rights of the petitioners in the properties companycerned.
